Welcome to the DjinnBot documentation. Everything you need to go from zero to a fully autonomous AI development team.
Getting StartedInstall, configure, and run your first pipeline in under 5 minutes. Core ConceptsUnderstand agents, pipelines, memory, and the architecture. GuidesStep-by-step walkthroughs for Slack setup, custom agents, and more. ReferenceAPI endpoints, CLI commands, configuration options, and pipeline YAML. AdvancedCustom LLM providers, MCP tools, local models, and scaling.

Advanced topics for power users ‚Äî custom LLM providers, local models, scaling, and extending DjinnBot.
LLM ProvidersConfigure any LLM provider including local models and custom endpoints. Bot InterfacesCurrent and future chat interfaces beyond Slack. Local DevelopmentSet up the development environment without Docker. Security ModelContainer isolation, secret management, and access control.
DjinnBot agents can interact through multiple interfaces. Currently Slack and the built-in dashboard chat are supported, with more platforms planned.
data.api-only#API-Only: The REST API and SSE streaming already allow building custom frontends. Any application that can make HTTP requests can interact with DjinnBot agents.
data.architecture-for-new-interfaces#Architec:
Adding a new chat interface involves:
Bridge service ‚Äî connects to the external platform‚Äôs API (similar to packages/slack/) Event routing ‚Äî maps platform events to DjinnBot‚Äôs event bus Per-agent identity ‚Äî manages bot accounts/tokens for each agent Thread mapping ‚Äî links platform threads to pipeline runs The engine‚Äôs event-driven architecture makes this straightforward ‚Äî new interfaces subscribe to Redis events and publish commands back.
data.contributing-an-interface#Contributing a:
If you want to add support for a new platform, the Slack package (packages/slack/) is the reference implementation. The key files:
slack-bridge.ts ‚Äî routes events between Slack and the engine agent-slack-runtime.ts ‚Äî manages per-agent Socket Mode connections thread-manager.ts ‚Äî maps runs to Slack threads slack-streamer.ts ‚Äî streams agent output to Slack messages A new interface would implement the same patterns for a different platform.
data.custom-webhooks#Custom Webhooks: A generic webhook interface will allow integration with any chat platform or custom application. Send messages in, receive agent responses out, via simple HTTP.
data.dashboard-chat#Dashboard Chat:
The built-in chat interface at http://localhost:3000/chat requires no additional setup. Features:
Select any agent and model Full tool access (code execution, file operations, web research) Persistent chat history Real-time streaming responses Supports onboarding and project-context sessions This is the primary interface for users who don‚Äôt use Slack.
data.discord#Discord: Discord bot support is on the roadmap. The architecture mirrors Slack ‚Äî each agent gets its own bot account, pipeline runs create threads, and agents respond to mentions.
data.microsoft-teams#Microsoft Teams: Teams integration is planned for enterprise environments that standardize on the Microsoft ecosystem.
data.slack#Slack:
Each agent gets its own Slack bot via Socket Mode. See Slack Bot Setup for configuration.
Features:
Per-agent bot identity (name, avatar) Pipeline threads (watch agents collaborate) Direct mentions and DMs Active/passive thread participation

data: DjinnBot supports a wide range of LLM providers through pi-mono. You can use cloud APIs, local models, or any OpenAI-compatible endpoint.

data.custom-providers-openai-compatible#Custo:
You can add any OpenAI-compatible endpoint as a custom provider through the dashboard:
Go to Settings ‚Üí Providers Click Add Custom Provider Enter: Provider name/slug Base URL (e.g., http://localhost:11434/v1 for Ollama) API key (if required) Use the model in agent config: custom-myollama/llama3.3 This works with:
Ollama ‚Äî local models with OpenAI-compatible API LM Studio ‚Äî local model runner vLLM ‚Äî production inference server text-generation-webui ‚Äî with OpenAI extension LocalAI ‚Äî drop-in OpenAI replacement Any OpenAI-compatible API endpoint
data.extended-thinking#Extended Thinking:
Some models support extended thinking (reasoning tokens). Configure per-agent:
thinking_level: medium # off, low, medium, high Supported models include Claude Sonnet 4+, Claude Opus 4+, and other reasoning-capable models. The system automatically detects which models support thinking.
data.global-defaults#Global Defaults:
Set in the dashboard Settings page:
Default working model ‚Äî used when no model is specified Default thinking model ‚Äî used for extended reasoning
data.local-models-via-ollama#Local Models via:
To use local models:
Install Ollama on your host Pull a model: ollama pull llama3.3 Ollama serves at http://localhost:11434/v1 by default Add as a custom provider in DjinnBot settings: Base URL: http://host.docker.internal:11434/v1 (use host.docker.internal from inside Docker) No API key needed Set agent model: custom-ollama/llama3.3 Local models work for chat and simple tasks but may not reliably produce structured output or use tools. For production pipeline execution, cloud models (Claude, GPT-4, Kimi) are recommended.
data.memory-search-provider#Memory Search Pro:
ClawVault‚Äôs semantic search (QMDR) uses a separate provider for embeddings and reranking. By default, this uses OpenRouter with:
Embeddings: openai/text-embedding-3-small Reranking: openai/gpt-4o-mini (LLM-based reranking) Configure via environment variables:
QMD_OPENAI_API_KEY=${OPENROUTER_API_KEY} QMD_OPENAI_BASE_URL=https://openrouter.ai/api/v1 QMD_EMBED_PROVIDER=openai QMD_OPENAI_EMBED_MODEL=openai/text-embedding-3-small QMD_RERANK_PROVIDER=openai QMD_RERANK_MODE=llm QMD_OPENAI_MODEL=openai/gpt-4o-mini These are set in docker-compose.yml for the engine service. Adjust if you want to use a different embedding provider.
data.per-agent#Per-Agent:
Set the default model in agents//config.yml:
model: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 thinking_model: anthropic/claude-opus-4 thinking_level: medium
data.per-pipeline-step#Per-Pipeline Step:
Override in pipeline YAML:
steps: - id: SPEC agent: eric model: anthropic/claude-opus-4 # Use Opus for requirements - id: IMPLEMENT agent: yukihiro model: openrouter/moonshotai/kimi-k2.5 # Use Kimi for coding
data.via-dashboard#Via Dashboard: Go to Settings ‚Üí Providers Enter API keys for each provider Keys are encrypted at rest using SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY Dashboard-configured keys take precedence over .env keys.
data.via-env-file#Via .env File:
Add API keys to your .env:
OPENROUTER_API_KEY=sk-or-v1-your-key ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-your-key OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-your-key
data.why-openrouter-is-recommended#Why OpenRo:
OpenRouter acts as a unified gateway ‚Äî one API key gives you access to every major model. This means:
Test different models per agent without managing multiple keys Fall back to alternative models if one is down Access the latest models as they launch Single billing for everything

data: DjinnBot takes security seriously with container isolation, encrypted secrets, and minimal attack surface.
data.authentication#Authentication:
DjinnBot does not currently include built-in authentication. The API and dashboard are open to anyone who can reach them on the network. This is fine for local development and private networks, but if you need to expose DjinnBot publicly, you must place it behind an authentication proxy.
Recommended options:
OAuth2 Proxy ‚Äî supports Google, GitHub, Azure AD, and dozens of other providers Authelia ‚Äî self-hosted SSO with 2FA Caddy with caddy-security ‚Äî simple reverse proxy with built-in auth Nginx with auth_request ‚Äî forward auth to an external provider Cloudflare Access ‚Äî zero-trust access without a VPN Built-in authentication (user accounts, API keys, RBAC) is on the near-term roadmap.
data.comparison-with-other-tools#Comparison w:
Unlike tools that execute agent code directly on the host:
DjinnBot agents cannot access your files outside their workspace DjinnBot agents cannot read your SSH keys, browser cookies, or environment DjinnBot agents cannot install packages on your system DjinnBot agents cannot run as root on your machine The container boundary is a hard security line. The worst case scenario is an agent doing damage inside its own ephemeral container, which is destroyed after the step completes.
data.container-isolation#Container Isolation:
Every agent runs in its own Docker container. This provides:
Filesystem isolation ‚Äî agents cannot access the host filesystem Process isolation ‚Äî agents cannot see or interact with host processes Network isolation ‚Äî containers are on a private bridge network No Docker socket ‚Äî agent containers cannot spawn other containers Ephemeral execution ‚Äî containers are destroyed after each step, leaving no persistent state outside the data volume The engine container has Docker socket access (required to spawn agent containers), but this is limited to the engine service only. Agent containers receive no Docker socket access.
data.credential-injection#Credential Injectio: Provider API keys are injected into agent containers as environment variables ‚Äî they‚Äôre never baked into images or written to disk. The engine fetches keys from the database and passes them to containers at runtime.
data.default-configuration#Default Configurat:
The default Docker Compose setup exposes services on localhost:
Service Bound To Port Dashboard 0.0.0.0:3000 3000 API 0.0.0.0:8000 8000 mcpo 0.0.0.0:8001 8001 PostgreSQL 0.0.0.0:5432 5432 Redis 0.0.0.0:6379 6379
data.encryption-at-rest#Encryption at Rest:
User-defined secrets (API keys, SSH keys, tokens) are encrypted with AES-256-GCM before storage in PostgreSQL. The encryption key is configured via SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY in .env.
# Generate a strong encryption key python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_hex(32))" Without SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY, secrets are encrypted with an ephemeral key that changes on restart ‚Äî making stored secrets permanently unrecoverable. Always set this in production.
data.internal-network#Internal Network: All DjinnBot services communicate on the djinnbot_default Docker bridge network. Agent containers are attached to this network for Redis and API access, but cannot reach the host network.
data.mcp-proxy-authentication#MCP Proxy Authe:
The mcpo proxy is protected by MCPO_API_KEY. Agent containers receive this key to authenticate tool calls. Generate a strong key:
python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_urlsafe(32))"
data.production-hardening#Production Hardenin:
For production deployments:
Bind to localhost ‚Äî change port bindings to 127.0.0.1:PORT:PORT Reverse proxy ‚Äî put nginx or Caddy in front of the API and dashboard with TLS Firewall ‚Äî block external access to PostgreSQL, Redis, and mcpo ports Change defaults ‚Äî update PostgreSQL password, mcpo API key, and encryption key

Understand how DjinnBot works under the hood. These concepts form the foundation of everything the platform does.
ArchitectureHow the services, event bus, and containers fit together. AgentsPersonas, memory, tools, and the files that define an agent. PipelinesYAML workflow definitions with steps, loops, and branching. Memory SystemClawVault, semantic search, wiki-links, and knowledge graphs. SkillsOn-demand instruction sets agents load when they need them. MCP ToolsExternal tool servers via the mcpo proxy. Pulse ModeAutonomous agent wake-up cycles for ongoing work. Agent ContainersIsolated Docker environments with full toolboxes. Secrets ManagementEncrypted credential storage with per-agent access control.

Agents are the core of DjinnBot. Each agent is a specialized AI persona with its own identity, expertise, memory, and tools. They‚Äôre not generic LLM wrappers ‚Äî they‚Äôre characters with opinions and domain knowledge.
data.agent-files#Agent Files:
Every agent is defined by a directory under agents/:
agents/eric/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ IDENTITY.md # Name, origin, role, emoji ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SOUL.md # Deep personality, beliefs, anti-patterns, voice ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ AGENTS.md # Workflow procedures, collaboration triggers, tool usage ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ DECISION.md # Memory-first decision framework ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ PULSE.md # Autonomous wake-up routine ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.yml # Model, pulse schedule, thinking settings ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ slack.yml # Slack bot credentials (optional)
data.agent-templates#Agent Templates:
Shared templates in agents/_templates/ provide common workflow and memory instructions that all agents inherit:
AGENTS.md ‚Äî environment description, git workflow, memory tools, communication tools DECISION.md ‚Äî memory-first decision framework PULSE.md ‚Äî autonomous wake-up routine with project tools MEMORY_TOOLS.md ‚Äî detailed memory tool reference with examples When creating a new agent, these templates provide the baseline behavior. Agent-specific files add role-specific expertise on top.
data.agentsmd#AGENTS.md:
The workflow file. This tells the agent exactly how to do their job:
Session startup ‚Äî what to do every time they wake up (read SOUL, search memories) Step-by-step procedures ‚Äî detailed workflows for their role Collaboration triggers ‚Äî when to loop in other agents Tool usage ‚Äî how to use memory, research, messaging, and domain tools Templates ‚Äî output formats and document structures
data.business-agents#Business Agents: Agent Role Expertise Holt Marketing & Sales Sales strategy, outreach, deal management Luke SEO Specialist Content strategy, keyword research, technical SEO Jim Finance Lead Budget, pricing, runway, financial modeling Business agents currently work in chat and pulse modes. Structured marketing/sales pipeline support is on the roadmap.
data.configyml#config.yml:
Runtime configuration for the agent:
model: xai/grok-4-1-fast-reasoning # Default LLM model thinking_model: xai/grok-4-1-fast-reasoning # Model for thinking/reasoning thinking_level: 'off' # off, low, medium, high thread_mode: passive # passive or active Slack mode pulse_enabled: false # Autonomous pulse mode pulse_interval_minutes: 30 # How often to wake up pulse_columns: # Which kanban columns to check - Backlog - Ready pulse_container_timeout_ms: 120000 # Max container runtime pulse_blackouts: # Don't pulse during these times - label: Nighttime start_time: '23:00' end_time: '07:00' type: recurring All configuration can be edited through the dashboard Settings page.
data.creating-custom-agents#Creating Custom A:
To create a new agent:
Create a directory under agents/ with the agent‚Äôs ID Add at minimum IDENTITY.md, SOUL.md, and config.yml Copy AGENTS.md, DECISION.md, and PULSE.md from agents/_templates/ and customize Restart the engine to pick up the new agent The agent will immediately be available in the dashboard for chat sessions and can be referenced in pipeline YAML files.
data.decisionmd#DECISION.md:
A memory-first decision framework shared across agents:
Search memories before every response Create memories when learning something new Reflect on interactions for self-improvement Stay in character and add value
data.engineering-pipeline-agents#Engineering: Agent Role Pipeline Stages Expertise Eric Product Owner SPEC Requirements, user stories, scope, prioritization Finn Solutions Architect DESIGN, REVIEW Architecture, tech decisions, code review Shigeo UX Specialist UX User flows, design systems, accessibility Yukihiro Senior SWE IMPLEMENT, FIX Writing code, debugging, implementation Chieko Test Engineer TEST QA, test strategy, regression detection Stas SRE DEPLOY Infrastructure, deployment, monitoring Yang DevEx Specialist DX (on-demand) CI/CD, tooling, developer workflow
data.how-agents-execute#How Agents Execute:
When an agent is assigned a pipeline step or chat message:
The engine spawns a Docker container from Dockerfile.agent-runtime The container loads the agent‚Äôs persona files (IDENTITY + SOUL + AGENTS + DECISION) ClawVault memories are loaded and injected as context Skills matching the task keywords are auto-injected The agent receives the step input (with template variables resolved) The agent works ‚Äî calling tools, writing files, running commands Output streams back to the engine via Redis pub/sub Memories are saved on session end The container is destroyed Each execution is stateless at the container level ‚Äî all persistence comes from the database, memory vaults, and git workspaces.
data.identitymd#IDENTITY.md:
The basics ‚Äî name, origin country, role title, emoji, and which pipeline stage(s) this agent handles.
# Eric ‚Äî Product Owner - **Name:** Eric - **Origin:** Denmark - **Role:** Product Owner - **Abbreviation:** PO - **Emoji:** üìã - **Pipeline Stage:** SPEC
data.pulsemd#PULSE.md: The autonomous wake-up routine for pulse mode. See Pulse Mode for details.
data.slackyml#slack.yml:
Slack bot credentials for this agent (see Slack Setup):
bot_token: ${SLACK_ERIC_BOT_TOKEN} app_token: ${SLACK_ERIC_APP_TOKEN}
data.soulmd#SOUL.md:
The personality file. This is what makes agents feel real. It includes:
Who they are ‚Äî backstory, experience, what shaped their approach Core beliefs ‚Äî principles forged through experience (e.g., ‚Äúvague specs produce vague results‚Äù) Anti-patterns ‚Äî things they refuse to do, with reasoning Productive flaws ‚Äî intentional trade-offs (e.g., Eric is ruthlessly aggressive about cutting scope) How they work ‚Äî their process for their domain Collaboration style ‚Äî how they interact with other agents Key phrases ‚Äî characteristic things they say The SOUL file is typically 100-200 lines of rich, specific character definition. This is injected into the agent‚Äôs system prompt.

data: DjinnBot is a distributed system built around an event-driven architecture. Here‚Äôs how the pieces fit together.
data.agent-containers#Agent Containers: Each agent step spawns a fresh Docker container built from Dockerfile.agent-runtime. See Agent Containers for details.
data.api-server-python--fastapi#API Server (P:
The API server is the central coordination point. It provides:
REST API ‚Äî all CRUD operations for runs, pipelines, agents, projects, settings, memory, etc. SSE streaming ‚Äî Server-Sent Events for real-time dashboard updates Database access ‚Äî PostgreSQL via SQLAlchemy with Alembic migrations GitHub webhooks ‚Äî receive events from GitHub for issue/PR integration Chat management ‚Äî session lifecycle for interactive agent conversations The API server does not execute agents. It stores state and serves the frontend.
data.dashboard-react--vite--tanstack-router#D:
A single-page application built with:
React with TypeScript TanStack Router for file-based routing Tailwind CSS for styling SSE for real-time streaming updates The dashboard talks directly to the API server ‚Äî there‚Äôs no backend-for-frontend. It‚Äôs served as static files by nginx in the Docker container.
data.event-flow#Event Flow:
Here‚Äôs what happens when you start a pipeline run:
Dashboard ‚Üí POST /v1/runs ‚Üí API Server creates run in PostgreSQL API Server ‚Üí publishes RUN_CREATED event ‚Üí Redis Streams Engine picks up event ‚Üí creates run state machine ‚Üí publishes STEP_QUEUED for first step Engine ‚Üí spawns Agent Container with persona, memories, and workspace Agent executes step ‚Üí streams output chunks via Redis Pub/Sub ‚Üí Engine relays to API Server ‚Üí Dashboard displays via SSE Agent completes ‚Üí Engine evaluates result ‚Üí routes to next step (or branches, retries, loops) Steps continue until pipeline completes or fails
data.mcpo-proxy#mcpo Proxy: The mcpo proxy exposes MCP tool servers as REST/OpenAPI endpoints. See MCP Tools for details.
data.monorepo-structure#Monorepo Structure:
DjinnBot is a Turborepo monorepo with npm workspaces:
packages/ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ core/ # Engine, events, memory, container management (TypeScript) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ server/ # API server (Python/FastAPI) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ dashboard/ # Web UI (React/TypeScript) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ slack/ # Slack bridge and per-agent bots (TypeScript) ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ agent-runtime/ # Container entrypoint and tools (TypeScript) The core package contains the bulk of the orchestration logic ‚Äî the pipeline engine, Redis event bus, container runner, ClawVault memory integration, skill registry, MCP manager, chat session manager, and more.
data.pipeline-engine-typescript--nodejs#Pipel:
The engine is the brain of the system. It:
Runs the state machine ‚Äî advances pipeline steps based on events Spawns agent containers ‚Äî creates isolated Docker containers for each agent step Manages memory ‚Äî loads/saves ClawVault memories for each agent session Bridges Slack ‚Äî routes events to Slack threads and processes agent mentions Manages MCP ‚Äî writes tool server config and monitors health via the McpoManager Processes events ‚Äî subscribes to Redis Streams for reliable, ordered event delivery The engine communicates with agent containers via Redis pub/sub ‚Äî sending commands (run step, send message) and receiving events (output chunks, tool calls, completion).
data.postgresql-state-store#PostgreSQL (State:
All persistent state lives in PostgreSQL:
Pipeline run state and history Step outputs and timing Agent configuration Project boards and tasks Settings and provider configuration MCP server registry Chat session messages Secrets (encrypted at rest)
data.redis-event-bus#Redis (Event Bus):
Redis serves two roles:
Streams ‚Äî reliable, ordered event delivery between the API server and engine. Events like RUN_CREATED, STEP_QUEUED, STEP_COMPLETE flow through Redis Streams. Pub/Sub ‚Äî real-time communication between the engine and agent containers. The engine sends commands, agents publish output chunks and events.

data: Every agent session runs in an isolated Docker container. This is one of DjinnBot‚Äôs key differentiators ‚Äî agents get a full engineering environment without any host access.
data.container-lifecycle#Container Lifecycle:
Spawn ‚Äî engine creates a new container via Docker API Mount ‚Äî shared data volume is mounted, symlinks are set up for agent home directory Inject ‚Äî persona files, memories, secrets, and environment variables are provided Execute ‚Äî agent runtime starts, processes the step or chat message Stream ‚Äî output flows to engine via Redis pub/sub Destroy ‚Äî container is removed when the step completes Each step gets a fresh container ‚Äî there‚Äôs no state leaking between steps. Persistence comes from:
Data volume ‚Äî shared across containers for memory vaults and workspaces Database ‚Äî PostgreSQL stores step outputs, chat history, etc. Git ‚Äî code changes are committed and pushed
data.customization#Customization:
To add tools to the agent container, modify Dockerfile.agent-runtime and rebuild:

data: DjinnBot agents can use external tools through the Model Context Protocol (MCP). An mcpo proxy runs MCP tool servers, and DjinnBot converts them into native agent tools at runtime ‚Äî agents use them exactly like built-in tools with no difference in the interface.
data.configuration#Configuration:
MCP servers are configured in mcp/config.json:
{ "mcpServers": { "github": { "command": "/usr/local/bin/github-mcp-server", "args": ["stdio", "--read-only", "--toolsets", "context,repos,issues"], "env": { "GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN": "${GITHUB_TOKEN}" } }, "time": { "command": "uvx", "args": ["mcp-server-time", "--local-timezone=Europe/Lisbon"] } } } Each entry specifies:
command ‚Äî the executable to run args ‚Äî command-line arguments env ‚Äî environment variables (supports ${VAR} substitution from the host)
data.custom-mcp-servers#Custom MCP Servers:
You can add any MCP-compatible tool server. The community maintains hundreds of servers for various APIs and services. Some popular ones:
Filesystem ‚Äî file operations outside the workspace Postgres/MySQL ‚Äî direct database access Slack ‚Äî Slack API operations Brave Search ‚Äî web search Playwright ‚Äî browser automation See awesome-mcp-servers for a comprehensive list.
data.default-tools#Default Tools:
DjinnBot ships with these MCP servers pre-configured:
Server Tools Description github Repository browsing, issues, context GitHub API access (read-only by default) fetch Web page fetching Retrieve content from URLs time Current time/timezone Time-aware operations grokipedia Wikipedia search Knowledge lookup
data.health-monitoring#Health Monitoring:
The engine‚Äôs McpoManager continuously monitors tool server health:
On startup, it polls each server endpoint Server status (running/error/configuring) is tracked in the database Tool discovery extracts available tools from each server‚Äôs OpenAPI schema Logs are streamed to Redis and visible in the dashboard
data.how-it-works#How It Works:
At startup, the engine:
Reads each MCP server‚Äôs OpenAPI schema from the mcpo proxy Converts every operation into a native AgentTool with proper parameter schemas Registers them alongside built-in tools (read, write, bash, etc.) When an agent calls an MCP tool, the code handles the HTTP request to mcpo internally ‚Äî the agent never sees URLs, curl commands, or HTTP details. Tool calls appear in the dashboard UI identically to built-in tools via the standard toolStart/toolEnd events.
Agent calls tool ‚Üí Engine makes HTTP request ‚Üí mcpo Proxy ‚Üí stdio ‚Üí MCP Server This means adding a new MCP server immediately gives agents new native tools with no code changes.
data.security#Security:
The mcpo proxy is protected by an API key (MCPO_API_KEY in .env). Agent containers receive this key and include it in their requests.
Environment variables in mcp/config.json use ${VAR} syntax ‚Äî the actual values come from the Docker environment, not the config file. Sensitive tokens never appear in the config.
data.via-api#Via API: POST /v1/mcp/ { "name": "My Tool Server", "description": "Does useful things", "config": { "command": "npx", "args": ["my-mcp-server"], "env": {} }, "enabled": true }
data.via-config-file#Via Config File: Edit mcp/config.json directly. The proxy watches the file and reloads automatically.
data.via-dashboard#Via Dashboard: Go to MCP Tools in the dashboard Click Configure or Add Server Enter the server configuration The proxy hot-reloads ‚Äî no restart needed

data: DjinnBot agents have persistent memory that survives across sessions. They remember decisions, learn from mistakes, and build knowledge over time. This is powered by ClawVault with semantic search via QMDR.
data.browsing-memory#Browsing Memory:
You can browse and search agent memories through:
Dashboard ‚Äî the Memory page lets you view vaults and search semantically CLI ‚Äî djinnbot memory search eric "architecture decisions" API ‚Äî GET /v1/memory/search?agent_id=eric&query=architecture
data.how-it-works#How It Works:
Every agent has two memory vaults:
Personal vault (data/vaults//) ‚Äî private memories only this agent can access Shared vault (data/vaults/shared/) ‚Äî team-wide knowledge all agents can read and write Memories are stored as markdown entries with metadata (type, tags, timestamps) and connected via wiki-links for graph traversal.
data.memory-lifecycle#Memory Lifecycle: Wake ‚Äî when an agent session starts, ClawVault loads relevant memories into context Recall ‚Äî during execution, agents search memories semantically before making decisions Remember ‚Äî agents save important findings, decisions, and lessons Checkpoint ‚Äî during long sessions, memories are periodically saved Sleep ‚Äî on session end, a summary is saved with next steps
data.recall--search-memories#recall ‚Äî Searc:
recall("search query", { limit: 5, profile: "default" }) Profiles optimize retrieval for different contexts:
Profile Use Case default General purpose retrieval planning Task planning and project context incident Errors, bugs, and lessons learned handoff Session continuity information
data.remember--save-to-vault#remember ‚Äî Sav:
remember(type, "Title", "Content with details", { shared: true, // Share with all agents tags: ["tag1"] // For search filtering }) Memory types:
Type When to Use lesson Learned from a mistake or success decision Important choice with rationale pattern Recurring approach that works fact Important information about the project/team preference How someone or something prefers to work handoff Context for resuming work later
data.semantic-search#Semantic Search:
Memory search uses embeddings for semantic similarity, not just keyword matching. When an agent calls recall("how we handle authentication"), it finds memories about auth patterns even if they don‚Äôt contain the exact word ‚Äúauthentication.‚Äù
The search pipeline:
Query expansion ‚Äî the query is expanded to capture related concepts Embedding ‚Äî query is converted to a vector via text-embedding-3-small Retrieval ‚Äî nearest neighbors found in the SQLite-backed vector store Reranking ‚Äî results are reranked using gpt-4o-mini for relevance Injection ‚Äî top results are injected into the agent‚Äôs context All embedding and reranking runs through OpenRouter ‚Äî no local GPU or model downloads required.
data.the-anchor-pattern#The Anchor Pattern:
Every project should have a root anchor memory that links to all related knowledge:
remember("fact", "Project: MyApp", "Root anchor for project MyApp.
" + "Goal: [[MyApp: Goal]]
" + "Tech: [[MyApp: Tech Stack]]
" + "Scope: [[MyApp: V1 Scope]]", { shared: true, tags: ["project:myapp", "project-anchor"] } ) Subsequent memories link back to the anchor, keeping the graph connected.
data.wiki-link-knowledge-graph#Wiki-Link Know:
Memories are connected using [[wiki-link]] syntax:
remember("decision", "MyApp: Tech Stack", "[[Project: MyApp]] will use FastAPI + PostgreSQL. " + "Considered Django (rejected: too opinionated) and Express (rejected: need Python). " + "See also [[MyApp: Architecture]], [[MyApp: API Design]].", { shared: true, tags: ["project:myapp", "architecture"] } ) These links create a traversable knowledge graph. When an agent recalls context about a project, they start from [[Project: Name]] and follow links to discover related information.

data: Pipelines are YAML files that define multi-agent workflows. Each pipeline describes a series of steps, which agents handle them, and how results flow between steps.
data.bugfix#bugfix:
For diagnosing and fixing bugs:
FIX ‚Üí VALIDATE 2 agents: Yukihiro (diagnose + fix), Chieko (validate).
data.creating-custom-pipelines#Creating Custo:
Create a YAML file in pipelines/ and it will automatically appear in the dashboard. No restart needed ‚Äî the API reads pipeline definitions from disk.
A minimal custom pipeline:
id: my-pipeline name: My Custom Pipeline version: 1.0.0 description: Does something useful defaults: model: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 tools: [read, write, bash] timeout: 600 agents: - id: yukihiro name: Yukihiro (SWE) steps: - id: DO_THING agent: yukihiro input: | Task: {{task_description}} Do the thing. outputs: [result] You can reference any agent defined in agents/ and use any combination of steps, branches, and loops.
data.engineering#engineering:
The full software development lifecycle:
SPEC ‚Üí DESIGN ‚Üí UX ‚Üí IMPLEMENT (loop) ‚Üî REVIEW ‚Üî TEST ‚Üí DEPLOY All 7 engineering agents participate. The IMPLEMENT step loops over a task breakdown, with each implementation reviewed and tested before moving on.
data.execute#execute: Runs a single task from a project board in an isolated container.
data.feature#feature:
A lighter pipeline for adding features to existing code:
DESIGN ‚Üí IMPLEMENT ‚Üî REVIEW ‚Üí TEST 3 agents: Finn (design + review), Yukihiro (implement), Chieko (test).
data.loop-steps#Loop Steps:
Steps can iterate over a list produced by a previous step:
- id: IMPLEMENT agent: yukihiro input: | Current Task: {{current_item}} Completed Tasks: {{completed_items}} loop: over: task_breakdown_json # Iterate over this output onEachComplete: REVIEW # After each item, go here onAllComplete: DEPLOY # After all items, go here The engine parses the JSON array and executes the step once per item, injecting {{current_item}}, {{completed_items}}, and {{progress_file}} template variables.
data.pipeline-structure#Pipeline Structure:
Every pipeline YAML has four sections:
# Metadata id: engineering name: Engineering Pipeline version: 1.0.0 description: Full software development workflow # Defaults applied to all steps defaults: model: openrouter/moonshotai/kimi-k2.5 tools: [read, write, bash] maxRetries: 3 timeout: 4800 # Agent declarations agents: - id: eric name: Eric (Product Owner) persona: docs/personas/eric.md tools: [web_search, read, write] # Step definitions steps: - id: SPEC agent: eric input: | You are the Product Owner. Task: {{task_description}} ... outputs: [product_brief, requirements_doc] onComplete: DESIGN
data.planning#planning:
Decomposes a project into tasks with dependency chains:
DECOMPOSE ‚Üí VALIDATE ‚Üí DECOMPOSE_SUBTASKS ‚Üí VALIDATE_SUBTASKS Uses structured output mode ‚Äî no tools, just constrained JSON. Eric breaks down the project, Finn validates and enriches. Then Eric creates bite-sized subtasks, and Finn validates those too. The output integrates directly with the project board.
data.result-routing#Result Routing:
Steps can branch based on agent output using onResult:
- id: REVIEW agent: finn outputs: [review_result, review_feedback] onResult: APPROVED: goto: TEST CHANGES_REQUESTED: goto: IMPLEMENT The agent writes a result value (e.g., APPROVED to REVIEW_RESULT.txt), and the engine routes to the matching branch.
data.steps#Steps:
Each step defines:
Field Description id Unique identifier (e.g., SPEC, DESIGN, IMPLEMENT) agent Which agent handles this step input The prompt template sent to the agent outputs Named outputs the agent produces onComplete Next step when this one succeeds onResult Conditional routing based on agent output loop Execute over a list of items model Override the default model for this step timeout Override the default timeout outputSchema JSON schema for structured output (no tools mode)
data.structured-output#Structured Output:
Steps can enforce structured JSON output using outputSchema:
- id: DECOMPOSE agent: eric outputSchema: name: task_breakdown strict: true schema: type: object properties: tasks: type: array items: type: object properties: title: { type: string } priority: { type: string, enum: [P0, P1, P2, P3] } estimatedHours: { type: number } required: [title, priority, estimatedHours] required: [tasks] When outputSchema is specified, the step uses direct API calls with constrained JSON output instead of tool-based execution. This guarantees valid, parseable output.

data: Pulse mode lets agents work autonomously on a schedule ‚Äî checking their inbox, finding tasks, and doing work without human intervention.
data.blackout-windows#Blackout Windows:
You can prevent agents from pulsing during certain times:
pulse_blackouts: - label: Nighttime start_time: '23:00' end_time: '07:00' type: recurring - label: Weekend start_time: '2026-03-01T00:00:00' end_time: '2026-03-03T00:00:00' type: one_off
data.communication#Communication:
Agents can communicate during pulse sessions:
message_agent(agentId, message) ‚Äî send a message to another agent‚Äôs inbox slack_dm(message) ‚Äî message the human via Slack DM (use sparingly ‚Äî only for urgent findings or blockers)
data.configuration#Configuration:
Pulse is configured per-agent in config.yml:
pulse_enabled: true pulse_interval_minutes: 30 pulse_columns: # Which kanban columns this agent checks - Backlog - Ready pulse_container_timeout_ms: 120000 pulse_max_consecutive_skips: 5 pulse_offset_minutes: 3 # Stagger to avoid all agents waking simultaneously pulse_blackouts: - label: Nighttime start_time: '23:00' end_time: '07:00' type: recurring pulse_transitions_to: # Allowed kanban transitions - planning - ready - in_progress All settings can be edited through the dashboard agent configuration page.
data.customizing-pulse-behavior#Customizing P:
Edit agents//PULSE.md to change what an agent does when it wakes up. For example, a QA agent might:
# Pulse Routine ### 1. Check for open PRs that need review Search for PRs assigned to you or your team. ### 2. Run regression tests Execute the test suite and report any failures. ### 3. Review recently merged code Check for untested code paths in recent merges. The engine doesn‚Äôt hard-code the routine ‚Äî it‚Äôs entirely defined by the markdown file you provide.
data.default-pulse-routine#Default Pulse Rout:
The default template covers:
Check inbox ‚Äî read messages from other agents Search memories ‚Äî recall recent context, handoffs, and active work Discover projects ‚Äî call get_my_projects() to find assigned projects Check work queue ‚Äî call get_ready_tasks(projectId) to find tasks in their columns Claim a task ‚Äî claim_task(projectId, taskId) atomically assigns the task and provisions a git workspace Do the work ‚Äî implement the task in the provisioned workspace Open a PR ‚Äî open_pull_request(projectId, taskId, title, body) when ready Transition the task ‚Äî move it through the kanban board (e.g., to ‚Äúreview‚Äù) Report ‚Äî message the human via Slack DM if there‚Äôs something important But you can rewrite PULSE.md to do anything ‚Äî check monitoring dashboards, run reports, review PRs, triage issues, or follow any custom workflow you define.
data.git-workflow#Git Workflow:
When an agent claims a task, the system:
Creates a feature branch: feat/task_abc123-implement-oauth Provisions a git workspace at /home/agent/task-workspaces/{taskId}/ Configures git credentials for push access The agent works in this workspace, commits, pushes, and opens a PR ‚Äî all within the isolated container.
data.how-pulse-works#How Pulse Works:
When pulse mode is enabled for an agent, the engine wakes them up on a configurable interval (default: every 30 minutes). Each pulse cycle is driven by the agent‚Äôs PULSE.md file ‚Äî a fully customizable markdown file that defines the agent‚Äôs wake-up routine.
The default template (agents/_templates/PULSE.md) provides a general-purpose routine, but each agent can override it with their own PULSE.md to define entirely different behavior. The file is injected as part of the agent‚Äôs system prompt during pulse sessions, so whatever instructions you write become the agent‚Äôs autonomous behavior.
data.project-tools#Project Tools:
During pulse sessions, agents have access to project management tools:
Tool Purpose get_my_projects() List assigned projects get_ready_tasks(projectId) Find tasks in your columns claim_task(projectId, taskId) Claim a task + provision git workspace get_task_context(projectId, taskId) Full task details and acceptance criteria open_pull_request(projectId, taskId, title, body) Open a GitHub PR transition_task(projectId, taskId, status) Move task through kanban execute_task(projectId, taskId) Kick off a pipeline run for the task

data: DjinnBot includes a built-in secrets management system for storing sensitive values ‚Äî API keys, tokens, SSH keys, and other credentials ‚Äî that agents need during execution.
data.agent-access-control#Agent Access Contro:
Secrets are not globally available to all agents. You explicitly grant each secret to specific agents:
Create a secret in the dashboard or via API Grant the secret to one or more agents Only granted agents receive the secret in their container environment This prevents agents from accessing credentials they don‚Äôt need.
data.encryption-key#Encryption Key:
The encryption key is configured via the SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY environment variable:
# Generate a strong key python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_hex(32))" Production requirement: Without SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY set, the system auto-generates an ephemeral key on first use. This key is lost if the database is reset or the service restarts without persisting it, making all stored secrets permanently unrecoverable. Always set this variable in production.
data.how-it-works#How It Works:
Secrets are stored in PostgreSQL, encrypted at rest with AES-256-GCM. The encryption scheme uses:
256-bit key derived from the SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY environment variable Random 96-bit nonce per encryption operation 128-bit authentication tag (GCM default) Storage format: base64(nonce[12] + tag[16] + ciphertext) Plaintext secret values are never returned by the API to the dashboard or any external client. All list and detail endpoints return masked previews only (e.g., ghp_...abc1).
data.how-secrets-reach-agents#How Secrets Rea:
When the engine spawns an agent container:
It calls the internal endpoint GET /v1/secrets/agents/{agent_id}/env The API decrypts the agent‚Äôs granted secrets and returns them as an environment variable map The engine injects these as environment variables into the container This is the only endpoint that returns plaintext values, and it‚Äôs an internal endpoint called only by the engine ‚Äî not exposed to the dashboard or external clients.
data.secret-types#Secret Types:
Secrets support different types to help organize credentials:
API keys ‚Äî third-party service credentials Tokens ‚Äî GitHub PATs, OAuth tokens, etc. SSH keys ‚Äî for git operations or server access Custom ‚Äî any sensitive value
data.security-properties#Security Properties: Secrets are encrypted before touching the database ‚Äî PostgreSQL never sees plaintext Each encryption uses a unique random nonce ‚Äî identical secrets produce different ciphertexts GCM authentication tags prevent tampering ‚Äî any modification is detected on decryption The dashboard and API only expose masked previews ‚Äî you can verify a secret exists without seeing its value Agent containers receive secrets only at spawn time via environment variables ‚Äî they‚Äôre not written to disk inside the container
data.via-api#Via API: # List secrets (masked, no plaintext) GET /v1/secrets/ # Create a secret POST /v1/secrets/ { "name": "GITHUB_TOKEN", "description": "GitHub PAT for repo access", "secret_type": "token", "value": "ghp_actual_secret_value" } # Grant to an agent POST /v1/secrets/{secret_id}/grant/{agent_id} # Revoke from an agent DELETE /v1/secrets/{secret_id}/grant/{agent_id} # List secrets granted to an agent (masked) GET /v1/secrets/agents/{agent_id} # Delete a secret (and all its grants) DELETE /v1/secrets/{secret_id}
data.via-dashboard#Via Dashboard: Go to Settings in the dashboard Navigate to the Secrets section Create, update, or delete secrets Grant or revoke agent access

data: Skills are on-demand instruction sets that agents can load when they need specialized knowledge. Instead of stuffing every possible instruction into an agent‚Äôs system prompt, skills are discovered and loaded contextually.
data.api#API: # List skills GET /v1/skills # Get a specific skill GET /v1/skills/{name}?agent_id=yukihiro # Create a skill POST /v1/skills { "name": "my-skill", "description": "Does something useful", "tags": ["relevant", "tags"], "content": "# My Skill\n\n...", "scope": "global" } # Toggle enabled state PATCH /v1/skills/{name}/enabled { "enabled": false }
data.automatic-matching#Automatic Matching:
The engine automatically matches skills to pipeline steps by comparing skill tags against the step input text. If a step mentions ‚Äúgithub‚Äù or ‚Äúpull request,‚Äù skills tagged with those keywords are auto-injected.
This means agents often get the right skills without explicitly calling load_skill().
data.creating-effective-skills#Creating Effec:
Good skills are:
Specific ‚Äî focused on one domain or task type Procedural ‚Äî step-by-step instructions, not vague guidance Tagged well ‚Äî keywords that match when agents encounter relevant tasks Example-rich ‚Äî show concrete examples of commands, code, and output
data.dashboard#Dashboard:
The Skills page in the dashboard lets you:
View all global and agent-specific skills Enable/disable skills without deleting them Edit skill content Create new skills
data.how-skills-work#How Skills Work: On session start, the agent receives a skill manifest ‚Äî a compact list of available skills with descriptions When the agent encounters a task that matches a skill, it calls load_skill("name") The full skill instructions are loaded into context The agent follows the skill‚Äôs procedures This keeps system prompts lean while giving agents access to deep, specialized knowledge when needed.
data.skill-file-format#Skill File Format:
Skills are markdown files with YAML frontmatter:
--- name: github-pr description: Opening and merging GitHub pull requests tags: [github, git, pr, pull-request, merge] enabled: true --- # GitHub PR Skill ## When to Use When you need to open a pull request, review PR changes, or merge branches. ## Steps 1. Ensure all changes are committed and pushed 2. Create PR with descriptive title and body 3. Link to relevant issue or task ...
data.skill-generator#Skill Generator: The dashboard includes a skill generator ‚Äî an AI-assisted chat session that helps you create new skills through conversation. Describe what the skill should cover and it writes the instructions.
data.skill-locations#Skill Locations:
Skills can be stored at two levels:
Location Scope Path Global Available to all agents agents/_skills/*.md Agent-specific Only for one agent agents//skills/*.md Agent-specific skills override global skills with the same name.

data.what-happens-next#What Happens Next:
The engineering pipeline assigns work through these stages:
SPEC (Eric) ‚Üí DESIGN (Finn) ‚Üí UX (Shigeo) ‚Üí IMPLEMENT (Yukihiro) ‚Üï REVIEW (Finn) ‚Üï TEST (Chieko) ‚Üì DEPLOY (Stas) Eric (Product Owner) reads your task description and produces requirements, user stories, and acceptance criteria Finn (Architect) takes Eric‚Äôs requirements and designs the architecture, API, database schema, and task breakdown Shigeo (UX) creates UX specifications and design system guidelines Yukihiro (SWE) implements each task from the breakdown ‚Äî writing actual code in an isolated container Finn reviews each implementation, approving or requesting changes Chieko (QA) tests approved implementations, passing or sending back for fixes Stas (SRE) handles deployment once all tasks pass Each agent runs in its own Docker container with a full toolbox ‚Äî they can read files, write code, run bash commands, use git, and more.

data.clone--configure#Clone \u0026amp; Config:
git clone https://github.com/BaseDatum/djinnbot.git cd djinnbot cp .env.example .env Open .env in your editor and set your API key:
# Required ‚Äî this is the only thing you must set OPENROUTER_API_KEY=sk-or-v1-your-key-here OpenRouter gives you access to Claude, GPT-4, Gemini, Kimi, and dozens of other models through a single API key. It‚Äôs the fastest way to get started. You can also use direct provider keys (Anthropic, OpenAI, etc.) ‚Äî see LLM Providers for details.

data.optional-encryption-key#Optional: Encryp:
For production deployments, generate a secrets encryption key:
# Generate and add to .env python3 -c "import secrets; print('SECRET_ENCRYPTION_KEY=' + secrets.token_hex(32))" >> .env This encrypts user-defined secrets (API keys, SSH keys, etc.) at rest. Without it, secrets are encrypted with an ephemeral key that resets on restart.
data.prerequisites#Prerequisites:
You need exactly two things:
Docker + Docker Compose ‚Äî Install Docker Desktop (includes Compose) An LLM API key ‚Äî OpenRouter is recommended (one key, access to all models) That‚Äôs it. No Node.js, no Python, no database setup. Docker handles everything.
data.start-services#Start Services:
docker compose up -d This starts 6 services:
Service Container Port Purpose PostgreSQL djinnbot-postgres 5432 State database Redis djinnbot-redis 6379 Event bus (Redis Streams) API Server djinnbot-api 8000 REST API (FastAPI) Pipeline Engine djinnbot-engine ‚Äî Orchestrates agent execution Dashboard djinnbot-dashboard 3000 React web interface MCP Proxy djinnbot-mcpo 8001 Tool server proxy Check that everything is healthy:
docker compose ps You should see all services running with healthy status.
data.verify#Verify:
Open the dashboard:
http://localhost:3000 Check the API:
curl http://localhost:8000/v1/status You should see a JSON response with "status": "ok" and connected service counts.
data.what-just-happened#What Just Happened:
Docker Compose built and started the entire stack:
PostgreSQL stores pipeline runs, steps, agent state, project boards, and settings Redis provides the event bus via Redis Streams ‚Äî reliable, ordered message delivery between services API Server (FastAPI/Python) exposes REST endpoints for the dashboard, CLI, and external integrations Pipeline Engine (TypeScript/Node) runs the state machine that coordinates agent execution, spawns agent containers, manages memory, and bridges Slack Dashboard (React/Vite) serves the web interface with real-time SSE streaming mcpo proxies MCP tool servers (GitHub, web fetch, etc.) as OpenAPI endpoints for agents When a pipeline runs, the engine dynamically spawns agent containers ‚Äî isolated Docker containers with a full engineering toolbox ‚Äî for each step. These are separate from the 6 core services and are created/destroyed per step.

data.loops#Loops:
Process a list of items with a single step:
- id: IMPLEMENT agent: yukihiro input: | Current Task: {{current_item}} Completed: {{completed_items}} loop: over: task_breakdown_json # JSON array from previous step onEachComplete: REVIEW # Run after each item onAllComplete: FINALIZE # Run when all items done
data.minimal-pipeline#Minimal Pipeline:
Create a file in pipelines/:
# pipelines/research.yml id: research name: Research Pipeline version: 1.0.0 description: Research a topic and produce a report defaults: model: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 tools: [read, write, bash] timeout: 600 agents: - id: eric name: Eric (PO) steps: - id: RESEARCH agent: eric input: | Research this topic thoroughly: {{task_description}} Write a comprehensive report to REPORT.md. outputs: [report] Drop this file in pipelines/ and it‚Äôs immediately available ‚Äî no restart needed.
data.multi-step-with-handoffs#Multi-Step with: id: content name: Content Pipeline version: 1.0.0 description: Research, write, and review content defaults: model: openrouter/moonshotai/kimi-k2.5 tools: [read, write, bash] timeout: 900 agents: - id: luke name: Luke (SEO) - id: holt name: Holt (Marketing) - id: finn name: Finn (Reviewer) steps: - id: RESEARCH agent: luke input: | Research keywords and outline for: {{task_description}} Write outputs: - KEYWORD_RESEARCH.md - CONTENT_OUTLINE.md outputs: [keyword_research, content_outline] onComplete: WRITE - id: WRITE agent: holt input: | Write the content based on this research: {{keyword_research}} {{content_outline}} Write the full article to ARTICLE.md. outputs: [article] onComplete: REVIEW - id: REVIEW agent: finn input: | Review this content: {{article}} Output REVIEW_RESULT: APPROVED or CHANGES_REQUESTED outputs: [review_result, review_feedback] onResult: APPROVED: goto: DONE CHANGES_REQUESTED: goto: WRITE - id: DONE agent: luke input: | Finalize SEO metadata for: {{article}} outputs: [seo_metadata]
data.notifications#Notifications:
Notify agents when something important happens:
- id: DEPLOY agent: stas onResult: SUCCESS: notify: agent: eric message: "Deployment successful!" FAIL: notify: agent: yukihiro message: "Deployment failed, needs investigation" goto: FIX
data.per-step-model-override#Per-Step Model O:
Use different models for different steps:
- id: SPEC agent: eric model: anthropic/claude-opus-4 # Expensive but thorough input: ... - id: IMPLEMENT agent: yukihiro model: openrouter/moonshotai/kimi-k2.5 # Fast and capable input: ...
data.pipeline-design-tips#Pipeline Design Tip: Start simple ‚Äî 2-3 steps is fine. Add complexity only when you need it. Use branching ‚Äî let agents route work based on quality checks (APPROVED/CHANGES_REQUESTED). Set timeouts ‚Äî prevent runaway steps from consuming resources. Enable retries ‚Äî transient failures (API errors, etc.) are common. maxRetries: 3 handles them. Name outputs clearly ‚Äî architecture_doc is better than output_1.
data.structured-output#Structured Output:
Force agents to produce valid JSON matching a schema:
- id: PLAN agent: eric outputSchema: name: task_list strict: true schema: type: object properties: tasks: type: array items: type: object properties: title: { type: string } priority: { type: string, enum: [P0, P1, P2, P3] } required: [title, priority] required: [tasks] input: | Break down this project into tasks: {{task_description}} outputs: [task_list_json]

Each DjinnBot agent can have its own Slack bot, appearing as a distinct team member in your workspace. This guide walks you through creating Slack apps for your agents.
Slack integration is optional. The built-in dashboard chat works without any Slack configuration. Set this up only if you want agents visible in your Slack workspace.
data.bot-doesnt-respond-to-mentions#Bot doesn: Verify the bot is invited to the channel Check that app_mention event subscription is enabled Confirm Socket Mode is enabled and tokens are correct Check engine logs: docker compose logs engine | grep -i slack

data.dms#DMs: Send a DM to any agent bot for a private conversation. Useful for quick questions or ad-hoc tasks.
data.mentions#Mentions: Mention an agent in any channel it‚Äôs in (@Eric what do you think about this feature?) and it will respond in character, using its full persona and memory.
data.overview#Overview:
Each agent needs its own Slack app because:
Agents post messages under their own name and avatar Each agent can be mentioned independently (@Eric, @Finn, etc.) Socket Mode allows real-time bidirectional communication Each bot has its own OAuth scopes and permissions You‚Äôll create one Slack app per agent, then add the tokens to your .env file.
data.pipeline-threads#Pipeline Threads: When a pipeline run starts, the engine creates a thread in the configured channel. Each step‚Äôs output is posted as replies in the thread, attributed to the agent handling that step. You can watch a full engineering pipeline unfold as a Slack conversation.
data.slack-resources#Slack Resources: Slack API Documentation Socket Mode Guide Bot Token Scopes Reference Agents & Assistants ‚Äî Slack‚Äôs AI bot framework Slack App Manifest ‚Äî automate app creation

data.step-1-create-a-slack-app#Step 1: Create:
For each agent you want in Slack:
Go to api.slack.com/apps Click Create New App ‚Üí From scratch Name it after the agent (e.g., ‚ÄúEric - Product Owner‚Äù) Select your workspace Click Create App
data.step-2-enable-ai-agent-features#Step 2::
Slack has released AI-powered features specifically for bots. Enable these to get the best experience:
In your app settings, go to Features in the sidebar Click Agents & AI Apps Toggle Enable Agent or Assistant to ON Under Agent Settings: Enable Dynamic Prompts ‚Äî this allows DjinnBot to provide rich, context-aware responses Enable Model Context Protocol ‚Äî this allows the agent to use MCP tools natively within Slack‚Äôs AI framework Click Save Changes Slack‚Äôs Agents & Assistants framework is what makes DjinnBot agents feel native in your workspace. With dynamic prompts enabled, agents can provide contextual suggestions and structured responses. With MCP enabled, agents can surface tool results directly in Slack threads. See Slack‚Äôs Agents & Assistants documentation for the latest on these features.
data.step-3-configure-oauth-permissions#Step:
Navigate to OAuth & Permissions and add these Bot Token Scopes:
Scope Purpose app_mentions:read Detect when the agent is @mentioned channels:history Read messages in public channels channels:read List channels chat:write Send messages files:read Access shared files files:write Upload files groups:history Read private channel messages groups:read List private channels im:history Read DMs im:read List DMs im:write Send DMs reactions:write Add emoji reactions users:read Look up user info
data.step-4-enable-socket-mode#Step 4: Enable:
Navigate to Socket Mode in the sidebar:
Toggle Enable Socket Mode to ON Give the app-level token a name (e.g., ‚Äúeric-socket‚Äù) Add the connections:write scope Click Generate Save the App-Level Token (xapp-...) ‚Äî this is the APP_TOKEN Socket Mode lets the bot connect without exposing a public URL, which is ideal for self-hosted deployments behind firewalls.
data.step-5-enable-events#Step 5: Enable Even:
Navigate to Event Subscriptions:
Toggle Enable Events to ON
Under Subscribe to bot events, add:
app_mention ‚Äî responds when someone @mentions the agent message.channels ‚Äî sees messages in channels it‚Äôs in message.groups ‚Äî sees messages in private channels message.im ‚Äî receives DMs Click Save Changes
data.step-6-install-to-workspace#Step 6: Inst:
Navigate to Install App:
Click Install to Workspace Review the permissions and approve Copy the Bot User OAuth Token (xoxb-...) ‚Äî this is the BOT_TOKEN
data.step-7-add-tokens-to-djinnbot#Step 7: Ad:
Edit your .env file and add the tokens for each agent:

Also create agents//slack.yml for each agent:
bot_token: ${SLACK_ERIC_BOT_TOKEN} app_token: ${SLACK_ERIC_APP_TOKEN}

data.thread-modes#Thread Modes:
Agents can operate in different thread modes:
passive ‚Äî only responds when directly mentioned active ‚Äî proactively participates in conversations (watches for relevant topics) Configure via thread_mode in the agent‚Äôs config.yml.

data.agent-configuration-configyml#Agent Conf:
Per-agent settings in agents//config.yml:
# LLM Model model: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 thinking_model: anthropic/claude-sonnet-4 thinking_level: 'off' # off, low, medium, high # Slack thread_mode: passive # passive or active # Pulse (autonomous mode) pulse_enabled: false pulse_interval_minutes: 30 pulse_offset_minutes: 3 pulse_max_consecutive_skips: 5 pulse_container_timeout_ms: 120000 pulse_columns: - Backlog - Ready pulse_transitions_to: - planning - ready - in_progress pulse_blackouts: - label: Nighttime start_time: '23:00' end_time: '07:00' type: recurring pulse_one_offs: [] All agent config can also be edited through the dashboard Settings and Agent pages.

data.available-tools#Available Tools:
Tools that can be listed in the tools array:
Tool Description read Read files from the workspace write Write files to the workspace edit Edit files with search/replace bash Execute shell commands grep Search file contents find Find files by pattern ls List directory contents web_search Search the web (via research tool) Agents also have access to built-in tools (memory, messaging, project management) that are always available regardless of the tools list.
data.loop-result-routing#Loop Result Routing:
Within a loop, use continueLoop: true to advance to the next item:
onResult: PASS: continueLoop: true # Move to next loop item FAIL: goto: IMPLEMENT # Go back to fix
data.result-routing#Result Routing:
The onResult field maps agent output values to step transitions:
onResult: APPROVED: goto: TEST CHANGES_REQUESTED: goto: IMPLEMENT FAIL: goto: FIX notify: agent: eric message: "Test failed, needs investigation" The agent writes the result value to a file named {OUTPUT}_RESULT.txt (e.g., REVIEW_RESULT.txt containing APPROVED).
data.step-fields#Step Fields: - id: string # Unique step identifier (e.g., SPEC, DESIGN) agent: string # Agent ID that handles this step input: | # Prompt template (supports {{variables}} and {% if %}) You are the Product Owner. Task: {{task_description}} outputs: # Named outputs the agent produces - product_brief - requirements_doc # Flow control (use exactly one) onComplete: string # Next step ID when this step succeeds onResult: # Conditional routing based on agent output APPROVED: goto: string # Go to step CHANGES_REQUESTED: goto: string notify: # Optional notification agent: string message: string # Loop execution loop: over: string # Output name containing JSON array to iterate onEachComplete: string # Step to run after each item onAllComplete: string # Step to run after all items # Overrides model: string # Override default model for this step timeout: number # Override default timeout # Structured output (mutually exclusive with tools) outputSchema: name: string strict: boolean schema: # JSON Schema object type: object properties: ... required: [...]
data.top-level-fields#Top-Level Fields: id: string # Unique pipeline identifier name: string # Display name version: string # Semantic version description: string # Pipeline description defaults: # Default values applied to all steps model: string # Default LLM model tools: [string] # Default tool list maxRetries: number # Default retry count (default: 0) timeout: number # Default timeout in seconds agents: # Agent declarations - id: string name: string persona: string # Path to persona files model: string # Override default model tools: [string] # Override default tools steps: # Pipeline step definitions - ...
